intro: Lapsana chondrilloides, commonly known as devil's-bit scabwort, is a flowering plant native to Europe, western Asia, and North Africa. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble a single flower. The plant typically grows in disturbed soils and can be found in meadows, roadsides, and waste areas. It has hairy, lance-shaped leaves and produces small yellow flowers arranged in clusters. The plant is known for its medicinal uses in traditional herbal remedies.
